summary: This is a formal letter from the French Ministry of Justice's Office for International Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters to the U.S. Department of Justice, explaining France's absolute legal principle of non-extradition of its nationals. It clarifies that this principle applies even to binationals and references the 1996 U.S.-France extradition treaty, while noting an exception for EU member states under the European Arrest Warrant.

persons.name: Andrew Finkelman
persons.context: Serves as the liaison magistrate at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, through whom the French Ministry of Justice is addressing the U.S. Department of Justice.

persons.name: Philippe Jaegle
persons.context: The signatory of the letter, identified as the head of the Office for the International Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters within the French Ministry of Justice.

events.title: Signing of U.S.-France Extradition Treaty
events.description: The bilateral extradition treaty between the United States and France was signed. Article 3 states the requested state is not bound to extradite its nationals, but the U.S. Executive Power may do so at its discretion.

events.title: French Law Transposing European Arrest Warrant
events.description: France enacted a law transposing the EU framework decision on the European Arrest Warrant, creating an exception to the non-extradition principle for EU member states.

events.title: EU Framework Decision on European Arrest Warrant
events.description: The European Union adopted a framework decision establishing the European Arrest Warrant, which forms the basis for the exception to France's non-extradition rule for EU members.

locations: Embassy of the United States of America in Paris
keyFacts: French law absolutely prohibits the extradition of any person who had French nationality at the time of the alleged crimes, regardless of any other nationalities they may hold.

France applies the principle 'aut dedere, aut judicare' (either extradite or prosecute), meaning if France refuses extradition based on nationality, it must prosecute the individual itself for acts committed abroad.

The U.S.-France extradition treaty (1996) explicitly allows France to refuse extradition of its nationals, while granting the U.S. Executive Branch the discretionary power to extradite U.S. nationals.
The only exception to France's non-extradition rule is for member states of the European Union, due to the European Arrest Warrant framework established in 2002/2004.
The document highlights a key legal asymmetry: the U.S. can and does extradite its nationals to France, but France systematically refuses to extradite French nationals to the U.S.
